standard_metadata.standard_description: Find a percent of a quantity as a rate per 100 (e.g., 30% of a quantity means 30/100 times the quantity); solve problems involving finding the whole, given a part and the percent.

question.content: The double number line shows that Henrik has a mass of $60\,\text{kg}$.    **Complete the table to show different percentages of Henrik's mass.**  Mass ($\text{kg}$) | Percentage -:|-:  | $100\%$ of $60\,\text{kg}$  | $20\%$ of $60\,\text{kg}$  | $40\%$ of $60\,\text{kg}$

images.alt: A double number line with 2 tick marks. The line labeled Mass, kilograms, reads from left to right: 0, 60. The line labeled Percentage, reads from left to right: 0 percent, 100 percent.

hints.content: The number lines show that the ratio of $\maroonD{\text{kilograms}}$ to $\blueE{\text{percentage}}$ is $\maroonD{60}:\blueE{100\%}$.  We are looking for ratios that are equivalent to $\maroonD{60}:\blueE{100\%}$.

$\blueE{100}\div\blueE{20} = \purpleE5$  So. we can find the mass for $\blueE{20\%}$ by dividing both parts of the ratio by $\purpleE{5}$.  [[☃ image 1]]  So $\blueE{20\%}$ of $\maroonD{60}$ is $\maroonD{12}$.

images.alt: A double number line with 3 unequally spaced tick marks. The line labeled Mass, kilograms, reads from left to right: 0, 12, 60. The line labeled Percentage, reads from left to right: 0 percent, 20 percent, 100 percent. An arrow from the pair 60 to 100 percent to the pair 12 to 20 percent is labeled divided by 5.

hints.content: Now we can find the mass for $\blueE{40\%}$ by multiplying both parts of the new ratio by $\purpleE{2}$.  [[☃ image 1]]  So $\blueE{40\%}$ of $\maroonD{60}$ is $\maroonD{24}$.

images.alt: A double number line with 4 unequally spaced tick marks. The line labeled Mass, kilograms, reads from left to right: 0, 12, 24, 60. The line labeled Percentage, reads from left to right: 0 percent, 20 percent, 40 percent, 100 percent. An arrow from the pair 12 to 20 percent to the pair 24 to 40 percent is labeled times 2.

hints.content: ###Completed table  Mass ($\text{kg}$) | Percentage -:|-: $60$ | $100\%$ of $60\,\text{kg}$ $12$ | $20\%$ of $60\,\text{kg}$ $24$ | $40\%$ of $60\,\text{kg}$

question.content: The double number line shows that a traffic signal allows traffic through the intersection for $36$ seconds.    **Complete the table to show different percentages of the time the signal allows.**  Time ($\text{s}$) | Percentage -:|-:  | $100\%$ of $36\,\text{s}$  | $25\%$ of $36\,\text{s}$  | $125\%$ of $36\,\text{s}$

images.alt: A double number line with 2 tick marks. The line labeled Time, seconds, reads from left to right: 0, 36. The line labeled Percentage, reads from left to right: 0 percent, 100 percent.

hints.content: The number lines show that the ratio of $\maroonD{\text{seconds}}$ to $\blueE{\text{percentage}}$ is $\maroonD{36}:\blueE{100\%}$.  We are looking for ratios that are equivalent to $\maroonD{36}:\blueE{100\%}$.

$\blueE{100}\div\blueE{25} = \purpleE{4}$  So. we can find the time for $\blueE{25\%}$ by dividing both parts of the ratio by $\purpleE{4}$.  [[☃ image 1]]  So $\blueE{25\%}$ of $\maroonD{36}$ is $\maroonD{9}$.

images.alt: A double number line with 3 unequally spaced tick marks. The line labeled Time, seconds, reads from left to right: 0, 9, 36. The line labeled Percentage, reads from left to right: 0 percent, 25 percent, 100 percent. An arrow from the pair 36 to 100 percent to the pair 9 to 25 percent is labeled divided by 4.

hints.content: Now we can find the time for $\blueE{125\%}$ by multiplying both parts of the new ratio by $\purpleE{5}$.  [[☃ image 1]]  So $\blueE{125\%}$ of $\maroonD{36}$ is $\maroonD{45}$.  This makes sense because $\blueE{125\%}$ is more than $\blueE{100\%}$. So it should represent more than $\maroonD{36\,\text{s}}$.

images.alt: A double number line with 4 unequally spaced tick marks. The line labeled Time, seconds, reads from left to right: 0, 9, 36, 45. The line labeled Percentage, reads from left to right: 0 percent, 25 percent, 100 percent, 125 percent. An arrow from the pair 9 to 25 percent to the pair 45 to 125 percent is labeled times 5.

hints.content: ###Completed table  Time ($\text{s}$) | Percentage -:|-: $36$ | $100\%$ of $36\,\text{s}$ $9$ | $25\%$ of $36\,\text{s}$ $45$ | $125\%$ of $36\,\text{s}$

question.content: The double number line shows that $42$ people watched Deon's new video today.    **Complete the table to show different percentages of the number of people who watched the video.**  People | Percentage -:|-:  | $100\%$ of $42$ people  | $50\%$ of $42$ people  | $150\%$ of $42$ people

images.alt: A double number line with 2 tick marks. The line labeled People, reads from left to right: 0, 42. The line labeled Percentage, reads from left to right: 0 percent, 100 percent.

hints.content: The number lines show that the ratio of $\maroonD{\text{people}}$ to $\blueE{\text{percentage}}$ is $\maroonD{42}:\blueE{100\%}$.  We are looking for ratios that are equivalent to $\maroonD{42}:\blueE{100\%}$.

$\blueE{100}\div\blueE{50} = \purpleE{2}$  So. we can find the people for $\blueE{50\%}$ by dividing both parts of the ratio by $\purpleE{2}$.  [[☃ image 1]]  So $\blueE{50\%}$ of $\maroonD{42}$ is $\maroonD{21}$.

images.alt: A double number line with 3 equally spaced tick marks. The line labeled People, reads from left to right: 0, 21, 42. The line labeled Percentage, reads from left to right: 0 percent, 50 percent, 100 percent. An arrow from the pair 42 to 100 percent to the pair 21 to 50 percent is labeled divided by 2.

hints.content: Now we can find the people for $\blueE{150\%}$ by multiplying both parts of the new ratio by $\purpleE{3}$.  [[☃ image 1]]  So $\blueE{150\%}$ of $\maroonD{42}$ is $\maroonD{63}$.  This makes sense because $\blueE{150\%}$ is more than $\blueE{100\%}$. So it should represent more than $\maroonD{42}$ people.

images.alt: A double number line with 4 equally spaced tick marks. The line labeled People, reads from left to right: 0, 21, 42, 63. The line labeled Percentage, reads from left to right: 0 percent, 50 percent, 100 percent, 150 percent. An arrow from the pair 21 to 50 percent to the pair 63 to 150 percent is labeled times 3.

hints.content: ###Completed table  People | Percentage -:|-: $42$ | $100\%$ of $42$ people $21$ | $50\%$ of $42$ people $63$ | $150\%$ of $42$ people

question.content: The double number line shows that Kimimela fed her rabbits $350$ days this year. Her foster brother fed them the other days.    **Complete the table to show different percentages of the days that Kimimela fed her rabbits.**  Time (days) | Percentage -:|-:  | $100\%$ of $350$ days  | $20\%$ of $350$ days  | $80\%$ of $350$ days

images.alt: A double number line with 2 tick marks. The line labeled Time, days, reads from left to right: 0, 350. The line labeled Percentage, reads from left to right: 0 percent, 100 percent.

hints.content: The number lines show that the ratio of $\maroonD{\text{days}}$ to $\blueE{\text{percentage}}$ is $\maroonD{350}:\blueE{100\%}$.  We are looking for ratios that are equivalent to $\maroonD{350}:\blueE{100\%}$.

$\blueE{100}\div\blueE{20} = \purpleE{5}$  So. we can find the time for $\blueE{20\%}$ by dividing both parts of the ratio by $\purpleE{5}$.  [[☃ image 1]]  So $\blueE{20\%}$ of $\maroonD{350}$ is $\maroonD{70}$.

images.alt: A double number line with 3 unequally spaced tick marks. The line labeled Time, days, reads from left to right: 0, 70, 350. The line labeled Percentage, reads from left to right: 0 percent, 20 percent, 100 percent. An arrow from the pair 350 to 100 percent to the pair 70 to 20 percent is labeled divided by 5.

hints.content: Now we can find the time for $\blueE{80\%}$ by multiplying both parts of the new ratio by $\purpleE{4}$.  [[☃ image 1]]  So $\blueE{80\%}$ of $\maroonD{350}$ is $\maroonD{280}$.

images.alt: A double number line with 4 unequally spaced tick marks. The line labeled Time, days, reads from left to right: 0, 70, 280, 350. The line labeled Percentage, reads from left to right: 0 percent, 20 percent, 80 percent, 100 percent. An arrow from the pair 70 to 20 percent to the pair 280 to 80 percent is labeled times 4.

hints.content: ###Completed table  Time (days) | Percentage -:|-: $350$ | $100\%$ of $350$ days $70$ | $20\%$ of $350$ days $280$ | $80\%$ of $350$ days

question.content: The tape diagram shows that Bolívar takes $40$ minutes to steam a batch of tamales.    **Complete the table to show different percentages of the steaming time.**  Time ($\text{min}$) | Percentage -:|-:  | $100\%$ of $40\,\text{min}$  | $50\%$ of $40\,\text{min}$  | $250\%$ of $40\,\text{min}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 5 equal parts. The first 2 parts are shaded. A curved brace above the first 2 parts is labeled 40. A curved brace below the first 2 parts is labeled 100 percent.

hints.content: The tape diagram shows that the ratio of minutes to percentage is $\purpleD{40}:\purpleD{100\%}$.  We are looking for ratios that are equivalent to $\purpleD{40}:\purpleD{100\%}$.

###Finding $\purpleD{100\%}$ of $40$ minutes  $\purpleD{100\%}$ is the whole time, which is $\purpleD{40}$ minutes.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueE{50\%}$ is $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{2}}$ of the time.  [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\maroonE{250\%}$ is $\maroonE{\dfrac{5}{2}}$ of the time.  [[☃ explanation 2]]  Now, we can use the same tape diagram to find $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{2}}$ of $\purpleD{40}$ minutes and $\maroonE{\dfrac{5}{2}}$ of $\purpleD{40}$ minutes.

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 5 equal parts. The first 2 parts are shaded. A curved brace above the first 2 parts is labeled 40. A curved brace below the first 2 parts is labeled 100 percent.

hints.content: ###Finding $\blueE{50\%}$ of $40$ minutes  Each part in the tape diagram is $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{2}}$ of $\purpleD{100\%}$. So it's also $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{2}}$ of $\purpleD{40}$ minutes.  $\purpleD{40}\times \dfrac{1}{2} = {20}$  Each part represents ${20}$ minutes.  [[☃ image 2]]  So, the ratio $\purpleD{40}:\purpleD{100\%}$ is equivalent to $\blueE{20}:\blueE{50\%}$.  In other words, $\blueE{50\%}$ of $\purpleE{40}$ is $\blueE{20}$.

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 5 equal parts, each labeled 20. The first part is shaded. A curved brace below the first part is labeled 50 percent. A curved brace below the first 2 parts is labeled 100 percent.

hints.content: ###Finding $\maroonE{250\%}$ of $40$ minutes  $\maroonE{250\%}$ is $\maroonE{\dfrac{5}{2}}$ of the time.  So it takes $ {5}$ parts to represent $\maroonE{250\%}$ of $\purpleD{40}$ minutes.  [[☃ image 1]]  Each part represents ${20}$ minutes.  $\blueE{20}\times {5} = \maroonE{100}$  So, the ratio $\purpleD{40}:\purpleD{100\%}$ is equivalent to $\maroonE{100}:\maroonE{250\%}$.  In other words, $\maroonE{250\%}$ of $\purpleE{40}$ is $\maroonE{100}$.  This makes sense because $\maroonE{250\%}$ is more than $\purpleD{100\%}$. So it should represent more than $\purpleD{40}$ minutes.

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 5 equal parts, each labeled 20. All 5 parts are shaded. A curved brace below the first part is labeled 50 percent. A curved brace below the first 2 parts is labeled 100 percent. A curved brace below the entire tape is labeled 250 percent.

hints.content: ###Completed table  Time ($\text{min}$) | Percentage -:|-: $\purpleD{40}$ | $\purpleE{100\%}$ of $40\,\text{min}$ $\blueE{20}$ | $\blueE{50\%}$ of $40\,\text{min}$ $\maroonE{100}$ | $\maroonE{250\%}$ of $40\,\text{min}$

question.content: The tape diagram shows that Shanice spent $120$ minutes researching for debate club last week.    **Complete the table to show different percentages of Shanice's research time.**  Time ($\text{min}$) | Percentage -:|-:  | $100\%$ of $120\,\text{min}$  | $10\%$ of $120\,\text{min}$  | $110\%$ of $120\,\text{min}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 11 equal parts. The first 10 parts are shaded. A curved brace above the first 10 parts is labeled 120. A curved brace below the first 10 parts is labeled 100 percent.

hints.content: The tape diagram shows that the ratio of minutes to percentage is $\purpleD{120}:\purpleD{100\%}$.  We are looking for ratios that are equivalent to $\purpleD{120}:\purpleD{100\%}$.

###Finding $\purpleD{100\%}$ of $\purpleD{120}$ minutes  $\purpleD{100\%}$ is the whole time, which is $\purpleD{120}$ minutes.  [[☃ image 1]]  Now, we can use the same tape diagram to find $\blueE{10\%}$ of $\purpleD{120}$ minutes and $\maroonE{110\%}$ of $\purpleD{120}$ minutes.

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 11 equal parts. The first 10 parts are shaded. A curved brace above the first 10 parts is labeled 120. A curved brace below the first 10 parts is labeled 100 percent.

hints.content: ###Finding $\blueE{10\%}$ of $\purpleD{120}$ minutes  $\blueE{10\%}$ is $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ of the time. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\purpleD{120}\times \blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}} = \blueE{12}$  Each part represents $\blueE{12}$ minutes.  [[☃ image 2]]  So, the ratio $\purpleD{120}:\purpleD{100\%}$ is equivalent to $\blueE{12}:\blueE{10\%}$.  In other words, $\blueE{10\%}$ of $\purpleD{120}$ is $\blueE{12}$.

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 11 equal parts, each labeled 12. The first part is shaded. A curved brace below the first part is labeled 10 percent. A curved brace below the first 10 parts is labeled 100 percent.

hints.content: ###Finding $\maroonE{110\%}$ of $\purpleD{120}$ minutes  $\maroonE{110\%}$ is $\maroonE{\dfrac{11}{10}}$ of the time. [[☃ explanation 1]]  So it takes ${11}$ parts to represent $\maroonE{110\%}$ of $\purpleD{120}$ minutes.  [[☃ image 1]]  Each part represents $\blueE{12}$ minutes.  $\blueE{12}\times {11} = \maroonE{132}$  So, the ratio $\purpleD{120}:\purpleD{100\%}$ is equivalent to $\maroonE{132}:\maroonE{110\%}$.  In other words, $\maroonE{110\%}$ of $\purpleE{120}$ is $\maroonE{132}$.  This makes sense because $\maroonE{110\%}$ is more than $\purpleD{100\%}$. So it should represent more than $\purpleD{120}$ minutes.

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 11 equal parts, each labeled 12. All 11 parts are shaded. A curved brace below the first part is labeled 10 percent. A curved brace below the first 10 parts is labeled 100 percent. A curved brace below the entire tape is labeled 110 percent.

hints.content: ###Completed table  Time ($\text{min}$) | Percentage -:|-: $\purpleD{120}$ | $\purpleD{100\%}$ of $\purpleD{120\,\text{min}}$ $\blueE{12}$ | $\blueE{10\%}$ of $\purpleD{120\,\text{min}}$ $\maroonE{132}$ | $\maroonE{110\%}$ of $\purpleD{120\,\text{min}}$

question.content: The tape diagram shows that there are $240$ students graduating from a high school this year.    **Complete the table to show different percentages of the graduating students.**  Students | Percentage -:|-:  | $100\%$ of $240$ students  | $25\%$ of $240$ students  | $75\%$ of $240$ students

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 4 equal parts. All 4 parts are shaded. A curved brace above the whole tape is labeled 240. A curved brace below the whole tape is labeled 100 percent.

hints.content: The tape diagram shows that the ratio of students to percentage is $\purpleD{240}:\purpleD{100\%}$.  We are looking for ratios that are equivalent to $\purpleD{240}:\purpleD{100\%}$.

###Finding $\purpleD{100\%}$ of $\purpleD{240}$ students  $\purpleD{100\%}$ is the whole group, which is $\purpleD{240}$ students.  [[☃ image 1]]  Now, we can use the same tape diagram to find $\blueE{25\%}$ of $\purpleD{240}$ students and $\maroonE{75\%}$ of $\purpleD{240}$ students.

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 4 equal parts. All 4 parts are shaded. A curved brace above the whole tape is labeled 240. A curved brace below the whole tape is labeled 100 percent.

hints.content: ###Finding $\blueE{25\%}$ of $\purpleD{240}$ students  $\blueE{25\%}$ is $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{4}}$ of the students. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\purpleD{240}\times \blueE{\dfrac{1}{4}} = \blueE{60}$  Each part represents $\blueE{60}$ students.  [[☃ image 2]]  So, the ratio $\purpleD{240}:\purpleD{100\%}$ is equivalent to $\blueE{60}:\blueE{25\%}$.  In other words, $\blueE{25\%}$ of $\purpleD{240}$ is $\blueE{60}$.

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 4 equal parts, each labeled 60. The first part is shaded. A curved brace below the first part is labeled 25 percent. A curved brace below the whole tape is labeled 100 percent.

hints.content: ###Finding $\maroonE{75\%}$ of $\purpleD{240}$ students  $\maroonE{75\%}$ is $\maroonE{\dfrac{3}{4}}$ of the students. [[☃ explanation 1]]  So it takes ${3}$ parts to represent $\maroonE{75\%}$ of $\purpleD{240}$ students.  [[☃ image 1]]  Each part represents $\blueE{60}$ students.  $\blueE{60}\times {3} = \maroonE{180}$  So, the ratio $\purpleD{240}:\purpleD{100\%}$ is equivalent to $\maroonE{180}:\maroonE{75\%}$.  In other words, $\maroonE{75\%}$ of $\purpleE{240}$ is $\maroonE{180}$.

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 4 equal parts, each labeled 60. The first 3 parts are shaded. A curved brace below the first part is labeled 25 percent. A curved brace below the first 3 parts is labeled 75 percent. A curved brace below the whole tape is labeled 100 percent.

hints.content: ###Completed table  Students | Percentage -:|-: $\purpleD{240}$ | $\purpleD{100\%}$ of $\purpleD{240}$ students $\blueE{60}$ | $\blueE{25\%}$ of $\purpleD{240}$ students $\maroonE{180}$ | $\maroonE{75\%}$ of $\purpleD{240}$ students

question.content: The double number line shows that Hiawatha, who is $24$ years old, is $75\%$ as old as Itzel is.    **Complete the table to show different percentages of Itzel's age.**  Age (years) | Percentage -:|-:  | $75\%$ of Itzel's age  | $25\%$ of Itzel's age  | $100\%$ of Itzel's age

images.alt: A double number line with 2 tick marks. The line labeled Age, years, reads from left to right: 0, 24. The line labeled Percentage, reads from left to right: 0 percent, 75 percent.

hints.content: The number lines show that the ratio of $\maroonD{\text{years}}$ to $\blueE{\text{percentage}}$ is $\maroonD{24}:\blueE{75\%}$.  We are looking for ratios that are equivalent to $\maroonD{24}:\blueE{75\%}$.
We can find the age for $\blueE{25\%}$ by dividing both parts of the ratio by $\purpleE{3}$.  [[☃ image 1]]  So $\blueE{25\%}$ of Itzel's age is $\maroonD{8}$ years.

images.alt: A double number line with 3 unequally spaced tick marks. The line labeled Age, years, reads from left to right: 0, 8, 24. The line labeled Percentage, reads from left to right: 0 percent, 25 percent, 75 percent. An arrow from the pair 24 to 75 percent to the pair 8 to 25 percent is labeled divided by 3.

hints.content: Now we can find the age for $\blueE{100\%}$ by multiplying both parts of the new ratio by $\purpleE{4}$.  [[☃ image 1]]  So $\blueE{100\%}$ of Itzel's is $\maroonD{32}$ years. That means Itzel is $\maroonD{32}$ years old.

images.alt: A double number line with 4 unequally spaced tick marks. The line labeled Age, years, reads from left to right: 0, 8, 24, 32. The line labeled Percentage, reads from left to right: 0 percent, 25 percent, 75 percent, 100 percent. An arrow from the pair 8 to 25 percent to the pair 32 to 100 percent is labeled times 4.

hints.content: ###Completed table  Age (years) | Percentage -:|-: $24$ | $75\%$ of Itzel's age $8$ | $25\%$ of Itzel's age $32$ | $100\%$ of Itzel's age

question.content: The double number line shows that Bira has ridden $28\,\text{m}$ on a , which is $80\%$ of a full rotation on the carousel.    **Complete the table to show different percentages of a full rotation on the carousel.**  Distance ($\text{m}$) | Percentage -:|-:  | $80\%$ of a rotation  | $20\%$ of a rotation  | $100\%$ of a rotation

images.alt: A double number line with 2 tick marks. The line labeled Distance, meters, reads from left to right: 0, 28. The line labeled Percentage, reads from left to right: 0 percent, 80 percent.

hints.content: The number lines show that the ratio of $\maroonD{\text{meters}}$ to $\blueE{\text{percentage}}$ is $\maroonD{28}:\blueE{80\%}$.  We are looking for ratios that are equivalent to $\maroonD{28}:\blueE{80\%}$.
We can find the distance for $\blueE{20\%}$ by dividing both parts of the ratio by $\purpleE{4}$.  [[☃ image 1]]  So $\blueE{20\%}$ of a rotation is $\maroonD{7\,\text{m}}$.

images.alt: A double number line with 3 unequally spaced tick marks. The line labeled Distance, meters, reads from left to right: 0, 7, 28. The line labeled Percentage, reads from left to right: 0 percent, 20 percent, 80 percent. An arrow from the pair 28 to 80 percent to the pair 7 to 20 percent is labeled divided by 4.

hints.content: Now we can find the distance for $\blueE{100\%}$ by multiplying both parts of the new ratio by $\purpleE{5}$.  [[☃ image 1]]  So $\blueE{100\%}$ of a rotation is $\maroonD{35\,\text{m}}$. That means Bira will ride $\maroonD{35\,\text{m}}$ in a full rotation of the carousel.

images.alt: A double number line with 4 unequally spaced tick marks. The line labeled Distance, meters, reads from left to right: 0, 7, 28, 35. The line labeled Percentage, reads from left to right: 0 percent, 20 percent, 80 percent, 100 percent. An arrow from the pair 7 to 20 percent to the pair 35 to 100 percent is labeled times 5.

hints.content: ###Completed table  Distance ($\text{m}$) | Percentage -:|-: $28$ | $80\%$ of a rotation $7$ | $20\%$ of a rotation $35$ | $100\%$ of a rotation

question.content: The double number line shows that $270$ people attended this year's auction, which is $125\%$ as many people as attended last year.    **Complete the table to show different percentages of last year's attendance.**  People | Percentage -:|-:  | $125\%$ of last year's attendance  | $25\%$ of last year's attendance  | $100\%$ of last year's attendance

images.alt: A double number line with 2 tick marks. The line labeled People, reads from left to right: 0, 270. The line labeled Percentage, reads from left to right: 0 percent, 125 percent.

hints.content: The number lines show that the ratio of $\maroonD{\text{people}}$ to $\blueE{\text{percentage}}$ is $\maroonD{270}:\blueE{125\%}$.  We are looking for ratios that are equivalent to $\maroonD{270}:\blueE{125\%}$.
We can find the number of people for $\blueE{25\%}$ by dividing both parts of the ratio by $\purpleE{5}$.  [[☃ image 1]]  So $\blueE{25\%}$ of last year's attendance is $\maroonD{54}$ people.

images.alt: A double number line with 3 unequally spaced tick marks. The line labeled People, reads from left to right: 0, 54, 270. The line labeled Percentage, reads from left to right: 0 percent, 25 percent, 125 percent. An arrow from the pair 270 to 125 percent to the pair 54 to 25 percent is labeled divided by 5.

hints.content: Now we can find the number of people for $\blueE{100\%}$ by multiplying both parts of the new ratio by $\purpleE{4}$.  [[☃ image 1]]  So $\blueE{100\%}$ of last year's attendance is $\maroonD{216}$ people. That means $\maroonD{216}$ people attended the auction last year.

images.alt: A double number line with 4 unequally spaced tick marks. The line labeled People, reads from left to right: 0, 54, 216, 270. The line labeled Percentage, reads from left to right: 0 percent, 25 percent, 100 percent, 125 percent. An arrow from the pair 54 to 25 percent to the pair 216 to 100 percent is labeled times 4.

hints.content: ###Completed table  People | Percentage -:|-: $270$ | $125\%$ of last year's attendance $54$ | $25\%$ of last year's attendance $216$ | $100\%$ of last year's attendance

question.content: The tape diagram shows that Ehecatl's hair, which is now $12\,\text{cm}$ long, is $60\%$ as long as it was before his haircut.    **Complete the table to show different percentages of Ehecatl's hair length before the haircut.**  Length ($\text{cm}$) | Percentage -:|-:  | $60\%$ of Ehecatl's old hair length  | $20\%$ of Ehecatl's old hair length  | $100\%$ of Ehecatl's old hair length

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 5 equal parts. The first 3 parts are shaded. A curved brace above the first 3 parts is labeled 12. A curved brace below the first 3 parts is labeled 60 percent.

hints.content: The tape diagram shows that the ratio of length to percentage is $\purpleD{12}:\purpleD{60\%}$.  We are looking for ratios that are equivalent to $\purpleD{12}:\purpleD{60\%}$.

###Finding $\purpleD{60\%}$ of Ehecatl's old hair length  $\purpleD{60\%}$ of the old length is $\purpleD{12\,\text{cm}}$.  [[☃ image 1]]  Now, we can use the same tape diagram to find $\blueE{20\%}$ and $\maroonE{100\%}$ of the old length.

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 5 equal parts. The first 3 parts are shaded. A curved brace above the first 3 parts is labeled 12. A curved brace below the first 3 parts is labeled 60 percent.

hints.content: ###Finding $\blueE{20\%}$ of Ehecatl's old hair length  Each part in the tape diagram is ${\dfrac{1}{3}}$ of $\purpleD{60\%}$ and ${\dfrac{1}{3}}$ of $\purpleD{12\,\text{cm}}$.  $\begin{align} \purpleD{60\%}\times \dfrac{1}{3} &= \blueE{20\%}\\\\ \purpleD{12}\times \dfrac{1}{3} &= \blueE{4} \end{align}$  Each part represents $\blueE{4\,\text{cm}}$.  [[☃ image 2]]  So, the ratio $\purpleD{12}:\purpleD{60\%}$ is equivalent to $\blueE{4}:\blueE{20\%}$.  In other words, $\blueE{20\%}$ of Ehecatl's old hair length is $\blueE{4\,\text{cm}}$.

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 5 equal parts, each labeled 4. The first part is shaded. A curved brace below the first part is labeled 20 percent. A curved brace below the first 3 parts is labeled 60 percent.

hints.content: ###Finding $\maroonE{100\%}$ of Ehecatl's old hair length  $\blueE{20\%} \times 5 = \maroonE{100\%}$  So it takes ${5}$ parts to represent $\maroonE{100\%}$ of Ehecatl's old hair length.  [[☃ image 1]]  Each part represents $\blueE{4\,\text{cm}}$.  $\blueE{4}\times {5} = \maroonE{20}$  So, the ratio $\purpleD{12}:\purpleD{60\%}$ is equivalent to $\maroonE{20}:\maroonE{100\%}$.  In other words, $\maroonE{100\%}$ of Ehecatl's old hair length is $\maroonE{20\,\text{cm}}$. That means Ehecatl's hair was $\maroonE{20\,\text{cm}}$ long before the haircut.

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 5 equal parts, each labeled 4. All 5 parts are shaded. A curved brace below the first part is labeled 20 percent. A curved brace below the first 3 parts is labeled 60 percent. A curved brace below the entire tape is labeled 100 percent.

question.content: The tape diagram shows that Odalis is $132\,\text{cm}$ tall, which is $150\%$ of their sister Dalia's height.    **Complete the table to show different percentages of Dalia's height.**  Height ($\text{cm}$) | Percentage -:|-:  | $150\%$ of Dalia's height  | $25\%$ of Dalia's height  | $100\%$ of Dalia's height

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 6 equal parts. All 6 parts are shaded. A curved brace above the whole tape is labeled 132. A curved brace below the whole tape is labeled 150 percent.

hints.content: The tape diagram shows that the ratio of height to percentage is $\purpleD{132}:\purpleD{150\%}$.  We are looking for ratios that are equivalent to $\purpleD{132}:\purpleD{150\%}$.

###Finding $\purpleD{150\%}$ of Dalia's height  $\purpleD{150\%}$ of Dalia's height is $\purpleD{132\,\text{cm}}$.  [[☃ image 1]]  Now, we can use the same tape diagram to find $\blueE{25\%}$ and $\maroonE{100\%}$ of Dalia's height.

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 6 equal parts. All 6 parts are shaded. A curved brace above the whole tape is labeled 132. A curved brace below the whole tape is labeled 150 percent.

hints.content: ###Finding $\blueE{25\%}$ of Dalia's height  Each part in the tape diagram is ${\dfrac{1}{6}}$ of $\purpleD{150\%}$ and ${\dfrac{1}{6}}$ of $\purpleD{132\,\text{cm}}$.  $\begin{align} \purpleD{150\%}\times \dfrac{1}{6} &= \blueE{25\%}\\\\ \purpleD{132}\times \dfrac{1}{6} &= \blueE{22} \end{align}$  Each part represents $\blueE{22\,\text{cm}}$.  [[☃ image 2]]  So, the ratio $\purpleD{132}:\purpleD{150\%}$ is equivalent to $\blueE{22}:\blueE{25\%}$.  In other words, $\blueE{25\%}$ of Dalia's height is $\blueE{22\,\text{cm}}$.

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 6 equal parts, each labeled 22. The first part is shaded. A curved brace below the first part is labeled 25 percent. A curved brace below the whole tape is labeled 150 percent.

hints.content: ###Finding $\maroonE{100\%}$ of Dalia's height  $\blueE{25\%} \times 4 = \maroonE{100\%}$  So it takes ${4}$ parts to represent $\maroonE{100\%}$ of Dalia's height.  [[☃ image 1]]  Each part represents $\blueE{22\,\text{cm}}$.  $\blueE{22}\times {4} = \maroonE{88}$  So, the ratio $\purpleD{132}:\purpleD{150\%}$ is equivalent to $\maroonE{88}:\maroonE{100\%}$.  In other words, $\maroonE{100\%}$ of Dalia's height is $\maroonE{88\,\text{cm}}$. That means Dalia is $\maroonE{88\,\text{cm}}$ tall.

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 6 equal parts, each labeled 22. The first 4 parts are shaded. A curved brace below the first part is labeled 25 percent. A curved brace below the first 4 parts is labeled 100 percent. A curved brace below the whole tape is labeled 150 percent.

hints.content: ###Completed table  Height ($\text{cm}$) | Percentage -:|-: $\purpleD{132}$ | $\purpleD{150\%}$ of Dalia's height $\blueE{22}$ | $\blueE{25\%}$ of Dalia's height $\maroonE{88}$ | $\maroonE{100\%}$ of Dalia's height

question.content: The tape diagram shows that Elizabeth spent $91$ minutes, which was $70\%$ of her study time for her language exam, on conversation practice.    **Complete the table to show different percentages of Elizabeth's study time.**  Time (minutes) | Percentage -:|-:  | $70\%$ of Elizabeth's study time  | $10\%$ of Elizabeth's study time  | $100\%$ of Elizabeth's study time

hints.content: The tape diagram shows that the ratio of minutes to percentage is $\purpleD{91}:\purpleD{70\%}$.  We are looking for ratios that are equivalent to $\purpleD{91}:\purpleD{70\%}$.

###Finding $\purpleD{70\%}$ of Elizabeth's study time  $\purpleD{70\%}$ of the study time is $\purpleD{91}$ minutes.  [[☃ image 1]]  Now, we can use the same tape diagram to find $\blueE{10\%}$ and $\maroonE{100\%}$ of the study time.

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 10 equal parts. The first 7 parts are shaded. A curved brace above the first 7 parts is labeled 91. A curved brace below the first 7 parts is labeled 70 percent.

hints.content: ###Finding $\blueE{10\%}$ of Elizabeth's study time  Each part in the tape diagram is ${\dfrac{1}{7}}$ of $\purpleD{70\%}$ and ${\dfrac{1}{7}}$ of $\purpleD{91}$ minutes.  $\begin{align} \purpleD{70\%}\times \dfrac{1}{7} &= \blueE{10\%}\\\\ \purpleD{91}\times \dfrac{1}{7} &= \blueE{13} \end{align}$  Each part represents $\blueE{13}$ minutes.  [[☃ image 2]]  So, the ratio $\purpleD{91}:\purpleD{70\%}$ is equivalent to $\blueE{13}:\blueE{10\%}$.  In other words, $\blueE{10\%}$ of Elizabeth's study time is $\blueE{13}$ minutes.

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 10 equal parts, each labeled 13. The first part is shaded. A curved brace below the first part is labeled 10 percent. A curved brace below the first 7 parts is labeled 70 percent.

hints.content: ###Finding $\maroonE{100\%}$ of Elizabeth's study time  $\blueE{10\%} \times 10 = \maroonE{100\%}$  So it takes ${10}$ parts to represent $\maroonE{100\%}$ of Elizabeth's study time.  [[☃ image 1]]  Each part represents $\blueE{13}$ minutes.  $\blueE{13}\times {10} = \maroonE{130}$  So, the ratio $\purpleD{91}:\purpleD{70\%}$ is equivalent to $\maroonE{130}:\maroonE{100\%}$.  In other words, $\maroonE{100\%}$ of Elizabeth's study time is $\maroonE{130}$ minutes. That means Elizabeth studied for $\maroonE{130}$ minutes.

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 10 equal parts, each labeled 13. All 10 parts are shaded. A curved brace below the first part is labeled 10 percent. A curved brace below the first 7 parts is labeled 70 percent. A curved brace below the entire tape is labeled 100 percent.

question.content: The tape diagram shows that Rita answered $14$ questions correctly on a post-test. Rita learned a lot in this unit, so that was $350\%$ as many questions as she answered correctly in the pre-test.    **Complete the table to show different percentages of the questions Rita answered correctly on the pre-test.**  Number of questions correct | Percentage -:|-:  | $350\%$ of the correct pre-test questions  | $50\%$ of the correct pre-test questions  | $100\%$ of the correct pre-test questions

hints.content: The tape diagram shows that the ratio of questions to percentage is $\purpleD{14}:\purpleD{350\%}$.  We are looking for ratios that are equivalent to $\purpleD{14}:\purpleD{350\%}$.

###Finding $\purpleD{350\%}$ of the correct pre-test questions  $\purpleD{350\%}$ of Rita's correct pre-test question is $\purpleD{14}$ questions.  [[☃ image 1]]  Now, we can use the same tape diagram to find $\blueE{50\%}$ and $\maroonE{100\%}$ of the correct pre-test questions.

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 7 equal parts. All 7 parts are shaded. A curved brace above the whole tape is labeled 14. A curved brace below the whole tape is labeled 350 percent.

hints.content: ###Finding $\blueE{50\%}$ of the correct pre-test questions  Each part in the tape diagram is ${\dfrac{1}{7}}$ of $\purpleD{350\%}$ and ${\dfrac{1}{7}}$ of $\purpleD{14}$ questions.  $\begin{align} \purpleD{350\%}\times \dfrac{1}{7} &= \blueE{50\%}\\\\ \purpleD{14}\times \dfrac{1}{7} &= \blueE{2} \end{align}$  Each part represents $\blueE{2}$ questions.  [[☃ image 2]]  So, the ratio $\purpleD{14}:\purpleD{350\%}$ is equivalent to $\blueE{2}:\blueE{50\%}$.  In other words, $\blueE{50\%}$ of the questions Rita answered correctly on the pretest is $\blueE{2}$ questions.

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 7 equal parts, each labeled 2. The first part is shaded. A curved brace below the first part is labeled 50 percent. A curved brace below the whole tape is labeled 350 percent.

hints.content: ###Finding $\maroonE{100\%}$ of the correct pre-test questions  $\blueE{50\%} \times 2 = \maroonE{100\%}$  So it takes ${2}$ parts to represent $\maroonE{100\%}$ of Rita's correct pre-test questions.  [[☃ image 1]]  Each part represents $\blueE{2}$ questions.  $\blueE{2}\times {2} = \maroonE{4}$  So, the ratio $\purpleD{14}:\purpleD{350\%}$ is equivalent to $\maroonE{4}:\maroonE{100\%}$.  In other words, $\maroonE{100\%}$ of the questions Rita answered correctly on the pre-test is $\maroonE{4}$ questions. That means Rita answered $\maroonE{4}$ questions correctly on the pre-test.

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 7 equal parts, each labeled 2. The first 2 parts are shaded. A curved brace below the first part is labeled 50 percent. A curved brace below the first 2 parts is labeled 100 percent. A curved brace below the whole tape is labeled 350 percent.

hints.content: ###Completed table  Number of questions correct | Percentage -:|-: $\purpleD{14}$ | $\purpleD{350\%}$ of the correct pre-test questions $\blueE{2}$ | $\blueE{50\%}$ of the correct pre-test questions $\maroonE{4}$ | $\maroonE{100\%}$ of the correct pre-test questions

question.content: The double number line shows that Jéssica lives $48\,\text{km}$ from the capitol.    **Complete the table to show different percentages of the distance.**  Distance ($\text{km}$) | Percentage :-:|:-: $48$ | $\%$ of $48\,\text{km}$ $12$ | $\%$ of $48\,\text{km}$ $60$ | $\%$ of $48\,\text{km}$

images.alt: A double number line with 2 tick marks. The line labeled Distance, kilometers, reads from left to right: 0, 48. The line labeled Percentage, reads from left to right: 0 percent, 100 percent.

hints.content: The number lines show that the ratio of $\maroonD{\text{kilometers}}$ to $\blueE{\text{percentage}}$ is $\maroonD{48}:\blueE{100\%}$.  We are looking for ratios that are equivalent to $\maroonD{48}:\blueE{100\%}$.
$\maroonD{48}\div12= \purpleE4$  So, we can find the percentage for $12\,\text{km}$ by dividing both parts of the ratio by $\purpleE{4}$.  [[☃ image 1]]  So $\blueE{25\%}$ of $48$ is $\maroonD{12}$.

images.alt: A double number line with 3 unequally spaced tick marks. The line labeled Distance, kilometers, reads from left to right: 0, 12, 48. The line labeled Percentage, reads from left to right: 0 percent, 25 percent, 100 percent. An arrow from the pair 48 to 100 percent to the pair 12 to 25 percent is labeled divided by 4.

hints.content: $\maroonD{60}\div\maroonD{12}=\purpleE{5}$  Now we can find the percentage for $\maroonD{60\,\text{km}}$ by multiplying both parts of the new ratio by $\purpleE{5}$.  [[☃ image 1]]  So $\blueE{125\%}$ of $48$ is $\maroonD{60}$.  This makes sense because $60\,\text{km}$ is farther than $48\,\text{km}$. So it should be more than $100\%$ of the distance.

images.alt: A double number line with 4 unequally spaced tick marks. The line labeled Distance, kilometers, reads from left to right: 0, 12, 48, 60. The line labeled Percentage, reads from left to right: 0 percent, 25 percent, 100 percent, 125 percent. An arrow from the pair 12 to 25 percent to the pair 60 to 125 percent is labeled times 5.

hints.content: ###Completed table  Distance (km) | Percentage -:|-: $48$ | $100\%$ of $48\,\text{km}$ $12$ | $25\%$ of $48\,\text{km}$ $60$ | $125\%$ of $48\,\text{km}$

question.content: The tape diagram shows that Sanara gave $70$ haircuts this week.    **Complete the table to show different percentages of the haircuts.**  Haircuts | Percentage -:|-: $70$ | $\%$ of $70$ haircuts $7$ | $\%$ of $70$ haircuts $63$ | $\%$ of $70$ haircuts

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 10 equal parts. All 10 parts are shaded. A curved brace above the entire tape is labeled 70. A curved brace below the entire tape is labeled 100 percent.

hints.content: The tape diagram shows that the ratio of haircuts to percentage is $\purpleD{70}:\purpleD{100\%}$.  We are looking for ratios that are equivalent to $\purpleD{70}:\purpleD{100\%}$.

###What percent is $\purpleD{70}$ out of $\purpleD{70}$ haircuts?  $\purpleD{70}$ haircuts is all of them, which is $\purpleD{100\%}$ of the haircuts.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueE{7}$ haircuts is $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ of the haircuts.  [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\maroonE{63}$ haircuts is $\maroonE{\dfrac{9}{10}}$ of the haircuts.  [[☃ explanation 2]]  Now, we can use the same tape diagram to find $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ of $\purpleD{100\%}$ and $\maroonE{\dfrac{9}{10}}$ of $\purpleD{100\%}$.

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 10 equal parts. All 10 parts are shaded. A curved brace above the entire tape is labeled 70. A curved brace below the entire tape is labeled 100 percent.

hints.content: ###What percent is $\blueE{7}$ out of $\purpleE{70}$ haircuts?  Each part in the tape diagram is $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ of $\purpleD{100\%}$. So it's also $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ of $\purpleD{70}$ haircuts.  $\purpleD{70}\times \blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}} = \blueE{7}$  Each part represents $\blueE{7}$ haircuts.  [[☃ image 2]]  So, the ratio $\purpleD{70}:\purpleD{100\%}$ is equivalent to $\blueE{7}:\blueE{10\%}$.  In other words, $\blueE{10\%}$ of $\purpleE{70}$ is $\blueE{7}$.

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 10 equal parts, each labeled 7. The first part is shaded. A curved brace below the first part is labeled 10 percent. A curved brace below the entire tape is labeled 100 percent.

hints.content: ###What percent is $\maroonE{63}$ out of $\purpleE{70}$ haircuts?  $\maroonE{63}$ haircuts is $\maroonE{\dfrac{9}{10}}$ of the haircuts.  So it takes ${9}$ parts to represent $\maroonE{63}$ haircuts.  [[☃ image 1]]  Each part represents $\blueE{10\%}$.  $\blueE{10\%}\times {9} = \maroonE{90\%}$  So, the ratio $\purpleD{70}:\purpleD{100\%}$ is equivalent to $\maroonE{63}:\maroonE{90\%}$.  In other words, $\maroonE{90\%}$ of $\purpleE{70}$ is $\maroonE{63}$.

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 10 equal parts, each labeled 7. The first 9 parts are shaded. A curved brace below the first part is labeled 10 percent. A curved brace below the first 9 parts is labeled 90 percent. A curved brace below the entire tape is labeled 100 percent.

hints.content: ###Completed table  Haircuts | Percentage -:|-: $\purpleD{70}$ | $\purpleD{100\%}$ of $70$ haircuts $\blueE{7}$ | $\blueE{10\%}$ of $70$ haircuts $\maroonE{63}$ | $\maroonE{90\%}$ of $70$ haircuts

hints.content: ###What percent is $\blueE{9}$ out of $\purpleE{90}$ teeth?  Each part in the tape diagram is $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ of $\purpleD{100\%}$. So it's also $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ of $\purpleD{90}$ teeth.  $\purpleD{90}\times \blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}} = \blueE{9}$  Each part represents $\blueE{9}$ teeth.  [[☃ image 2]]  So, the ratio $\purpleD{90}:\purpleD{100\%}$ is equivalent to $\blueE{9}:\blueE{10\%}$.  In other words, $\blueE{10\%}$ of $\purpleE{90}$ is $\blueE{9}$.

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 10 equal parts, each labeled 9. The first part is shaded. A curved brace below the first part is labeled 10 percent. A curved brace below the entire tape is labeled 100 percent.

hints.content: ###What percent is $\maroonE{27}$ out of $\purpleE{90}$ teeth?  $\maroonE{27}$ teeth is $\maroonE{\dfrac{3}{10}}$ of the teeth.  So it takes ${3}$ parts to represent $\maroonE{27}$ teeth.  [[☃ image 1]]  Each part represents $\blueE{10\%}$.  $\blueE{10\%}\times {3} = \maroonE{30\%}$  So, the ratio $\purpleD{90}:\purpleD{100\%}$ is equivalent to $\maroonE{27}:\maroonE{30\%}$.  In other words, $\maroonE{30\%}$ of $\purpleE{90}$ is $\maroonE{27}$.

images.alt: A tape diagram with one tape split into 10 equal parts, each labeled 9. The first 3 parts are shaded. A curved brace below the first part is labeled 10 percent. A curved brace below the first 3 parts is labeled 30 percent. A curved brace below the entire tape is labeled 100 percent.

hints.content: ###Completed table  Teeth | Percentage -:|-: $\purpleD{90}$ | $\purpleD{100\%}$ of $\purpleD{90}$ teeth $\blueE{9}$ | $\blueE{10\%}$ of $\purpleD{90}$ teeth $\maroonE{27}$ | $\maroonE{30\%}$ of $\purpleD{90}$ teeth
